reviewText:
PROTOTYPE 2 – REVIEW
Graphics (Environment 8/10, Models 7/10)        7.5                Animations        6/10                Sound        7/10                Music        7/10                Story        6/10                Gameplay        7.5/10                Inovation        7/10                TOTAL SCORE        7
Graphics

On the first sight on all settings max this game looks pretty nice, but after a couple of hours of gameplay the 'holes' of this game are starting to show ... but, sadly, not just in the graphics area.

Animations
The animations in this game are really disappointing, with bosses which have the same attack animations, people, enemies and soldiers that are just copies one of another. I think that Heller's animations are a small variety in such a 'copy-pasted' world.

Sound & Music

The voice acting and other sounds in this game were not really impressive but neither that bad at all.

Story
The story of a your character, James Heller, the war veteran who's been intentionally made into the one of the evolved by Alex Mercer, seemed not that good at all. Actually there were some missions that had some kind of cleverness and some elements that looked promising, but sadly just for a short period of time, because they just sank in the sea of other unimaginative and boring missions with just one goal - to clear all of the Mercer's companions and Mercer himself. End of story.
Maybe the memory cut-scenes with which you kind of progress in understading of the story and other side tasks and missions are the better part and enjoyment of the whole game, not just the story.

Gameplay
The gameplay beside the graphics thankfully isn't the weakest part of the game and seemed improved since the first game. Running, jumping and gliding trough the map which is divided into three sectors never gets old. There are plenty upgrades to unlock, side missions to complete and other bonuses to finish, which really extends the time of finishing the game.
Maybe the main problem is the fact, that you are overpowered to the most of the enemies, that's why deaths seem to happen only by an accident and not because of the difficulty of the game.
There isn't really much to do in the so called 'open world', beside completing the tasks that you are  given. Using your abilities to beat or  'punish' other NPC's in a free roam mode gets quickly boring, because of their dull personality and poor mechanics.

Conslusion
Prototype 2 could be so much more of what it is, beacuse it inherited such a promising name and some in-game elements that showed the possibilities that could turned this game into a one of a kind gaming experience. But, unfortunately, because of so many unimaginative and (rather) bad shortcuts the overall feeling of this game just falls apart.
Maybe there are 'reasons' why is that and why we just can't give this game a score above mediocrity and put it alongside other great and impressive titles.
Replay value: NOT really.

Recommended: Yes, but ONLY ON SALE!

reviewText:
Alright.
I completed Prototype 2 less than 5 minutes ago, and Prototype 1, I've played probably more than 200 hours in total.
Are they the same experience? NO. With a change of protagonist and a complete revamp of the abilities, upgrade system, and fighting mechanics, Prototype 1 and PRototype 2 are two very different (and both incredible) experiences.

The Abilities.
Instead of one ability equipped at a time, with a multitide of combos and attacks, P2 features 2 abilities assigned to Mouse Button 1 and 2. This makes combat simpler than P1, but not nessecarily better. P1 contains thousands of combinations to simply desecrate your enemies. P2 has much gorier attacks, special moves, and kill sequences, but P1 simply goes more in depth. If you wanna know more, play the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ game.

Upgrade System.
Prototype 1 had a currency based upgrade system in which you would collect EP (Evolution Points) in ludicrous amounts and spend them on upgrades, of which there were, I believe, over 100. Prototype 2 features a leveling system, in which the EP (still present) acts as experience points. Upon leveling, the player chooses a single upgrade. Whether either one is better, I can't say, because I didn't have a problem with either of them. They were acceptable mechanics that did what they were meant to. Can you really ask for more?

Fighting Mechanics.
Incredible. Please just play it. It's Incredible.

Story.
In my opinion, P2's story was FAR better than P1. The original Prototype has more of a focus on the hack and slash, kill everything, be a total badass through ACTIONS. P2, on the other hand, has more of an emotional story, in which the character (still badass, still ♥♥♥♥s ♥♥♥♥ up) is less cold, and is more emotional. I felt more immersed with Heller than with Mercer.

Final Thoughts
If you can spare the funds, ♥♥♥♥ING BUY IT. If you can't, you better start a damn trust fund, because both Prototype 1 and Prototype 2 are excellent, amazing games that give 2 amazing experiences.

SPOILER ALERT
The protagonist is black. Not once did I hear any sort of mention that he was black, nor did I hear a racial slur at any point. Nice. That's the way to go.

Rating

Sure ok m8 i r8 8/8

reviewText:
I strongly suggest not purchasing Prototype 2. Yes, it was fun. Yes, it was marginally well-designed. But over-all, the first one was much, much better. I'll explain why, and you can decide for yourself if my issues are overriding factors for you:

1. Graphics

Prototype 2 wins. I'll give it that. It's gorgeous. Poorly optimised, so you're gonna get a crap framerate, but it's gorgeous.

2. Control scheme

Prototype 1 takes the gold there. P1's controls are well-mapped by default and make sense once you become aquainted with them. P2 changes some core controls for no reason, and because of the way they're set up, rebinding them will not help.

3. Movement and parkour systems

P1 wins, but mostly because of the control setup. It just flows better, not only because it's been designed better, but also because the controls don't appear to have been designed for a race of crab people.

4. Gameplay

P1 and P2 are actually somewhat tied gameplay-wise. P1's open-world is far more enjoyable and feels more alive." Things do NOT despawn. I don't mean like they don't despawn for a long time

reviewText: I rather enjoyed the first Prototype game. It had its fair share of flaws, but few games let me feel as gosh-darn powerful. I could leap tall buildings in a single bound, bash a tank to pieces, run through a crowd of zombies leaving bloody chunks in my wake... what's not to love? So despite the mediocre reviews the sequel received, it was a no-brainer that game would end up in my library as well. And you know what? I'm glad it did. Like the original, it's not perfect but it's a fun - if gory - superhero fantasy adventure (or maybe super-villain).\n\nThe developers went with a more traditional method of storytelling (although they did go a bit heavy on the cut-scenes. but fortunately they are all skippable) and by the last third of the game the adventure does become somewhat repetitive. But the powers are still great and the controls have been streamlined since the original iteration, so it's even easier to become a weapon of mass devastation.

reviewText:
This is ridiculous. What have you done, Activision? Prototype was one of the best sandbox games I've ever played. The controls are awesome, the protagonist was interesting and Alex Mercer was one hell of a killing machine. Never had I experienced such freedom to wreak havoc and the leveling system was enjoyable.

Now, Prototype 2 is...  largely inferior to its predecessor, to say the very least. The protagonist is not charismatic at all and dumber than a box of nails. He's a much stereotypical videogame generic badass like only Activision knows how to do.

Very bad QTEs and a stupid and extremely invasive tutorial marks the first part of the game. I generally enjoy a quick in-game tutorial, but this is one of the worst I've ever seen. This gets especially ridiculous when the game stops the gameplay to show you something you had to figure out for yourself earlier to advance. I'm not five year old, mind you.

The great freedom you had in Prototype is now gone! The map is way smaller, and there is so much less to do. You can't choose your upgrades at will anymore! You have to wait until predetermined ''evolutions'' to add a point to one of a few attributes. And its not a new move, it's just statistics, like adding 10% sprint speed or 20% more damage. It's boring as hell.

Also, the character asset design took one hell of a hit. The texture quality of Heller and other NPC/PC is just dreadful, especially when you compare it to the otherwise well textured and lighted environment. I believe it's even worst than the first game.

The animation, to my surprise, is not very good either. The animation of vehicles during in-engine cutscenes is robotic, in a way similar to early 2000 games. I don't understand why the developper could not fix this.

Now, the technical problems... This will be a deal breaker for many people. This game is just terribly optimized. There is a HUGE memory leak problem that was never (and will never without a doubt) be fixed. This appear to be related to ATI graphics cards. I have a rather solid rig which can run pretty much anything right now at max settings and at a 1680x1050 resolution. I possess 8Gb of RAM + 2GB GRAM. The game can run for approx 30 minutes before the leak occupies all the allocated RAM and starts to lag horribly. This time interval may be smaller if you have a smaller amount of RAM or your system is less powerful. The solution is to alt-tab out of the game when this happen and then go back. The leak will still continue and therefore, you are stuck doing this every 30 minutes or so.

This is not a good game. It have many fragments of awesome, but the problems are just so many and so hard to get around that it just outweights its qualities. It's still Prototype though and you'll still have fun wreaking havoc around NYC (NYZ), but if that's all you wanted, go play the first. It got more moves and is funnier overall to play, while the graphics are sufficient to appreciate gameplay at this day.

I don't know what you did to Radical during development, Activision, but you killed them, and you killed Prototype.

I hate you for what you are doing to the gaming industry.
That's all I have to say.

reviewText:
I LOVE this game and played it four times over on the console, but the PC version is broken. There's a terrible memory leak problem that can cause every machine besides the most beastly of them (think more than 8 gigs of RAM) to have framerates in the 30s or lower from 60+ in a matter of minutes, and if you check your task manager, you can see the game is skyrocketing with RAM use as compared to most games. Now, you can make it go away by doing all sorts of PC gaming tricks, but mostly you will have to minimize and then re-open the game every few minutes. This is unacceptable for any game. Activision also does not support this game, if you try to get help from them then tell them that your desktop is custom built, they will simply tell you they do not support custom builds or laptops and hang up the phone. If you lie and say you have a pre-built machine (like Alienware) then they will tell you they're going to escalate the issue, but never get back to you.

Honestly, unless you have a TON of RAM or don't mind constantly minimizing/re-opening the game or changing the graphics options every few minutes, then I say buy it, it's one of the best sequels I've ever played in my life that improves upon the original in every way I can think of. If not for its bad PC port status, I would give this game a glowing review, but as it stands, I can't stand to play any more of it on PC with these glaring issues that will never be fixed because Activision only cares about their money-printing games.

EDIT: Works fine on my Windows 8 and Windows 8.1 laptop
Specs:
MSI GT70
Core i7 4700MQ
Nvidia GeForce GTX 770m 3gb
12 gb RAM
Running on a 7200 RPM HDD
40+ FPS on max settings 1920x1080 with low anti-aliasing

reviewText:
Absolutely fantastic game.  Playing on intel/nvidia, have had absolutely zero problems.

As to the gameplay itself, it kind of feels like I'm playing an amoral amalgamation of a bunch of the Marvel superheroes.  I've got the claws of Wolverine, the ability to knock people around like Magneto, the ability to shapeshift like Mystique, plus a variety of other things.

Just running around the city is a freaking joy, to be honest.  You run straight up buildings, glide through the air, jump crazy distances, pounce on enemies or poor random citizens as you please, etc.  It feels like Spiderman without any sort of web-swinging restrictions, or Batman without any sort of grappling restrictions.

To be clear, it's not a superhero game -- but it sure does feel more like one than any game I've played that actually features superheroes.  Then again, I'd classify the main character as mostly a villain
date: despite doing things that help the greater good."  My guy isn't concerned with saving random citizens from battles that break out; he actually freaking EATS them to regain health.  Or to shapeshift into their form and escape detection.\n\nBasically nobody in this game is a good person at all

reviewText:
At first I thought this game was broken... Once I fixed the lag issue I found that this is one of the most enjoyable third-person sandbox games for casual play, when I'm in the mood to lounge on the couch with a game pad, I turn on Steam's Big Picture Mode, launch the game and massacre the city for hours. The Radnet DLC add hours of challenges to beat friends high-scores.

Many ATI Radeon users have experienced a memory leak that has made Prototype 2 unplayable. This fix seems to eradicate the issue and locks the client at 30fps, almost perfectly stable.

1. Run Prototype 2 and disable Anti-Aliasing in the game client

2. Download and install Radeon Pro Preview http://www.radeonpro.info/download/
a. Create a profile for Prototype2.exe by searching in steamapps/common/prototype2
b. On the Tweaks" tab:
VSync control : Always on (Double VSync)
Dynamic Framerate C Keep up to : 30 FPS Max
c. On the "Advanced" tab:
Flip Queue Size = 1 (Set to 1 and Check to Enable)

3. Right click on the profile your created in RadeonPro and click "Apply Now"

4. Ensure RadeonPro is running and start the game normally.

5. Play the game and enjoy!"

reviewText:
A friend helped me laying my hands on this during the summer sale so Credits to Bram first! <3

So here it is - my review for 'Prototype 2' on Steam.
If you are interested in my opinion of the Original 'Prototype' game you can find the review here: http://steamcommunity.com/id/IvanDankov/recommended/10150/

So this time it's yet again your turn to stop Blackwatch" and the infection going on in "NYZ" but this time you are playing the role of the ex-military 'James Heller'. His team had an operation in ''NYZ'' but got killed when they encountered the main antagonist of the game: 'Alex Mercer'. -
Unlike his goal in Prototype 1 he now wants to take over the City and kind of re-populate with evolved made by him with similar abilities . As the only survivor of his attack.. he infectes you with the "Mercer Virus" and now the game begins.
We discover that it was Mercer killing his wife and daughter with his "second outbreak" of the mercer virus (first outbreak would be the one of 'Prototype 1') and now crave for revenge and make him suffer as we did.
During all this yet again alot of twists will come up and in the end you find yourself chasing after something way more important than 'Alex Mercer' himself..

Thats it from me about the story since I dont like revealing too much for potential buyers.
The gameplay stays more or less the same as in one with further improvements and a combat system to die for.
Its too much fun running
hoursPlayed: beating or body surfing your way through the City with an endless amout of ways to kill people
voteText:
new monsters and tons of side missions that can keep you busy for a good while. I even recommend buying the DLC "RADNET Access Pack" if it's on sale since it adds new activities and a ranking system for you and your friends that unlocks rewards and Skins for 'Heller' if you complete them.

The achievments are again just fun to attempt with good challenges and references to movies or other games.
The graphics though are a mixed bag to me...some of the textures just look like they are from 2002 while animations and especially 'Hellers' different forms look very detailed and cool. But overall they are perfect fitting for a game like that and I am sure it won't stand in your way.

Again I was using an Nvidia Graphics Card and haven't encountered any technical issues with that game on highest settings but I am aware that 'AMD' cards are horribly optimized in this game so I'd recommend to get it on console ('AMD' users) if you have one.

On sale both (Game + DLC) cost me ~ 10 bucks and I dare to say that its a good invenstment since you can spend a good amount of hours in this game trying to complete it 100%. If you just care about the Story (wich may not be the most interesting for everyone) you can leave the DLC behind and finish the main Story in about 10 hours then quit and have another game on your "Story-Completed-List".

Overall I can say that if you loved the first one you will cheat on it with PROTOTYPE 2.
Gameplay feels more satisfying than in any other third person game (with hack 'n slay elements ofc) and the over the top gore is just great.

I highly recommend yet another game of my list that I used to love back in 2012 / 2013 and now got it again on steam.
As always I hope that my review was good / helpful and you might have found something interesting for yourself.
Have a good day! :D"

reviewText: Prototype 2 is not perfect and there are a few things which need to do a better job next game - like the lack of variation in missions - , but nonetheless this is one of the most visceral, spectacular and brutal sandboxes out there. Like a lot of action games, the story needs a bit of work, but if you can overcome it's minor short comings, this game can be a whole lot of fun.You may have a few hiccups here and there, but there's plenty to do in Prototype 2. More times than not, you'll have a blast doing all of it.Prototype 2 is a decent open-world action game, that does not invent the wheel, but it does manage to offer solid amounts of entertainment, splattered with generous servings of blood and mayhem.My only real concern is that this PC version is very conservative in comparison with the console version, with minimal graphical improvements and imprecise mouse+keyboard controls.The three month delay could have been used to make the most of the PC capabilities in my opinion. A rather poor treatment for the PC gamers.

reviewText:
Taking place a year after the events in the first Prototype, Prototype 2 is gritty, bloody story about revenge. You play as James Heller, a soldier in the military, freshly made infected by the main character of the last game, Alex Mercer. He has given you the power to get revenge for your wife and daughter, who died because of what is known as the Mercer Virus, supposedly released by Blackwatch (the acting military force in the New York (or what's left of it). As the game progresses, while the missions you do may change, revenge remains your motive, and anything that stands in your way will be killed, blown up, or consumed.

I love the gameplay of Prototype 2. While it can get repetitive after too long, the effect of your attacks is oh so satisfying. Smash, cut, slice, dice, tear apart, and consume anyone that gets in your way, civilians and soldiers alike. Later in the game you can even drive tanks and fly in helicopters. There are 3 parts of the map that you unlock progressively through out the game, but I felt they did a good job with how long it takes you to unlock them. The story line isn't the greatest, until you get 2/3 into the game. The voice acting of the guy who played James Heller is amazing, and definitely gets you immersed in his character.
This is definitely one of my favorite games of all time. It's the definition of a bloody good time".

9/10 for me."

reviewText:
Definitely a love.
I've never made myself to complete a game fully in months. But i had to play this one just to know how the story ends. And I'm pretty amazed.
Story is very interesting when you pass the 30% of it but its also very short and you can complete it in 5 or 6 hours and maybe less if you ignore all collectibles and any side missions and achievements.
Graphics are also very much improvement against first game. Game also has many performance issues that never been patched. But they very much dodged me. I don't have AMD so i only turn of Raptr to play the game.
Gameplay is pretty much the same as first game. You can destroy everything with mashing a button and even destroy trees cuz we all know that trees in games are usually gods. You again can use abilities and run like a Flash, fly, scale buildings only using your legs and jump 5 meters high... Also u can fight zombies and mutants.. And an army.
.. Fun...
I would definitely recommend the game if you know how to dodge the performance issues.
Cheers.

reviewText:
Prototype 2 is the perfect example of how to create a sequel that somehow manages to less than the game that precedes it. While it maintains much of the same gameplay of the original everything has been cut down in size and scope. Smaller world, less enemies, less powers, less weapons, less vehicles, less moves, shorter storyline. Even the graphics are not as impressive. You could switch the numbers at the end of the two Prototype games and it would be more logical.

The combat is still great fun but with less enemies and less types of enemies fighting them becomes very predictable very quickly and with less powers, weapons and moves at your disposal you have very little option for mixing it up.

The movement scheme with the parkour and infected powers is still one of the greatest open world movement systems around but because New York City has been downsized quite severely and now exists in small zones you can't really take advantage of the movement the same way you could in the original.

Perhaps the biggest clue that this wasn't going to be an equal to the original comes in the form of the storyline and the character development. Instead of the mysterious and morally conflicted protagonist of the original Prototype 2 casts you as a random jar-head out for revenge but quickly goes on a mission to save the world in an all too predictable way. The storyline of Prototype was obviously concocted by someone that have never bothered to play the original, almost all of the major plot-points and revelations of the original are either ignored or contradicted directly. All the shades of morality have been sucked out of the game and instead of the morally ambiguous characters and grey story of the original we get a predictable story about a angelically inclined hero versus a bunch of bad guys that are portrayed like Joseph Mengeler's meaner older brother.

Don't bother with this game, the original was a great play and I still heartily recommend it but the sequel is simply not worth the bother.

reviewText:
Prototype 2 was an alright game. It wasn't terrible, but it wasn't that great. Some new additions, skills and abilities from the first game, but not much change other then the advancement of story line.

The story line takes place after Alex Mercer has released the virus and begun infecting New York City. He has become corrupt with power and seeks destruction. It almost seems generic as the first game, but still quite playable. I did enjoy it, as much as I could, but probably not as much as I did with the first Prototype. The story line did play out pretty well, but they could have done a much better job with this epidemic.

The combat system was alright as well. It had some new additions and skills to go with it, but like I mentioned before, not many. The combat is very gory. Much to be expected from a game of infection. The input of the combat didn't differ much from the first Prototype. I also think they could've done more with this as well. It's always from to drop from 1000ft to Ground Zero and devour someone for their health and identity. Always useful when trying to escape from the armed forces.

A lot of work and changes should have been made before release. I would recommend getting this on special if you are at all interested in this game. It's still a good game, just not a great game. I completed it in under 20 hours.

3/5

reviewText:
I don't understand why more people didn't play this game when it was released. This is one of my favourite games, it's fun, immersive and well designed. There are some technical problems with it now and it is a shame that the PC port isn't better.

I read today that there is a Biohazard collection available on PS4 and Xbone with both this, the first game and the DLC included. GameSpot reviewed it and just criticised how it's a bad port on those systems as well. They didn't mention any of the games strenghts which is normal actualy when it comes to the Prototype series but a big shame in my opinion.

With a few tweaks here on PC the game is running pretty good for me. However there are still some frame drops and some stuttering but this decreases in the later areas. It's a shame that I can't experience it with better performance but it's still an amazing game. Which I am enjoying alot regardless of these issues.

It's packed with interesting content, immersive menu screens, good sound design and a great athmosphere throughout.
I put a SweetFx profile on it too and it looks pretty good. It's just a shame nobody has modded in a HD remaster yet like they did with Remember Me for example.

Anyway, I highly recommend you buy and play this game, especially if it's on sale.
Grab the Radnet DLC too for more cool content.

Even with it's technical problems the game can still be enjoyed and is definitely worth playing.
I googled some fixes before I started and I'm having a blast with it now.

reviewText:
I liked the first Prototype. The combat and movement mechanics were fantastic, while the world felt full of life. It had an uncanny sense of complete chaos, like as it was hard to see the difference between civilians and zombies in the crowds. The second game builds on the world design from the first game and creates an even more believable sense of bewildering chaos. It’s so much that it’s hard to take in if you just stand and look at it all. Any ideas you might have of avoiding collateral damage quickly go out the window. You just can’t help killing crowds of innocents when dealing with the military or monsters in the city. The city is just too dense for combat.

Prototype 2 is a wasted opportunity. The world design is the perfect stage for any post-apocalyptic game. It’s teeming with details and history. The art department really went all out in creating a believable world. Even the sound design is impressive. It’s subtle, and has a carefully designed wide dynamic range. It’s full of details, like car tires squealing when an NPC slams the brakes to avoid hitting you. It’s a competent studio pulling out some of the best work of the generation. And it’s all ruined by the story.

I don’t know what they were thinking when they signed off on the script. Did someone high up decide that this was fine, because “it’s just a game”? The story and characters are about as shallow as they get. Nobody has anything resembling a personality or a story arc through the game. They all look different, but the way they speak, their motivations and their roles in the story is all devoid of texture or depth. It’s just flat and boring, and as a result you can’t get engaged in anything going on. The mechanics are all great, and the mission designs are acceptably good. But there’s no excitement to see what happens next.

Despite the abysmal story and characters I still had a good time playing the game, thanks to everything else being good. But make no mistake, this game is instantly forgettable. You barely know what’s going on even as it’s happening, because it’s all flat and monotone. It’s like going on a nice sightseeing trip through a nightmare vision of New York. But we’ve already seen plenty of those, so that might not have much novelty value. I wanted to play the game after playing Saints Row 4, because SR4 basically copy-pasted the game mechanics of Prototype. For the €5 I paid Prototype 2 was worth it, but I can’t get over what a wasted opportunity this was. Every other component is here for a phenomenal game, but they decided that players don’t care about story and that this level of ambition is fine. And it just isn’t.

reviewText:
I love this game, the campaign was around 11-12 hours on normal difficulty; so if it's on sale it's definatly worth a purchase. It does have a couple of problems however.

Firstly it is quite graphicly intensive, i have a decent PC that can play games like battlefield 4 on high/ultra settings and get 70-80 fps; however on this game with medium settings i only get around 60-70 fps 'SO BE AWARE'

Secondly it has a very bad issue with memory usage. For me, after about an hour playing, it starts to get really laggy & unplayable; which normally results in me having to restart the game (which is annoying if your in the middle of a mission)

Thirdly the game sometimes randomly CTD's without any warning, normally for me after around 2-4 hours playing.

Finally for me everytime I use the 'pack leader ability' my screen freezes, the game is still playing in the background as you can hear the audio and still target things, however you can't see your character just the frozen moment when you used the ability (this hinders the game as a couple of times during the story as you have to use the ability to complete missions)

Apart from these things, I have noticed a couple of glitches with wall running, stealth consumes and AI; but overall i would highly recommend this game.

IF IT IS ON OFFER GRAB IT!

EDIT: Since I upgraded some of my hardware the game either refuses to boot, or runs at around 3 FPS even with everything on low. So take care when choosing to buy this game or not.

reviewText:
Become A Ultimate Shape-Shifting Weapon

Taking place a year after the events in the first Prototype, Prototype 2 is gritty, bloody story about revenge. You play as James Heller, a soldier in the military, freshly made infected by the main character of the last game, Alex Mercer. He has given you the power to get revenge for your wife and daughter, who died because of what is known as the Mercer Virus, supposedly released by Blackwatch (the acting military force in the New York (or what's left of it). As the game progresses, while the missions you do may change, revenge remains your motive, and anything that stands in your way will be killed, blown up, or consumed.

9,9/10 Will like it

The game also has little replayability becuase the story is so linear and you obtain every power in every game you play you will find little reason to play the game again.  That being said I enjoyed the time I did spend during the 9+ hour main story so I have to give credit where its do.  7.5/10

reviewText:
Prototype 2 is a good sequel of the first game, with improved graphics and gameplay.

The difficulty of the sequel seems to be somewhat lower, the Insane difficulty being locked until you clear the game for the first time.

The animations can sometimes be choppy, most of the combos locking you down and preventing you from moving in any other direction but forward. Also, the verticality provided by the tall buildings is only enjoyable in parkour, with only 1 attack per weapon that targets airborne enemies or structures, the other ones just sending you like a comet towards the ground.

The graphics are okay for 2015, some of the ground / wall textures being low quality. Also, props like AC units, cars or other things you can throw are simple and look decent.

The pacing of the game tends to be fast, although the player can approach enemies in multiple ways, even with ranged attacks and military weapons. If you are playing close-range melee, chances are you won't even notice the low-quality textures or the dumb civilian AI...

The story is...compelling at most. I've completed the main story + all //BLACKNET sidequests (each one has 2-3 missions) in about 20 hours.

The soundtrack is nothing special, SFX being fair and the  voice acting being on the bright side.

As conclusion, here are my ratings for the game:


7.5 / 10  Graphics
7 / 10     Animations
7 / 10     Audio (OST + SFX)
7 / 10     Story
8 / 10     Gameplay

Overall: 7.3 / 10

reviewText: This is the sort of game I play to pass the time. It's worth getting if you're a fan of single player campaign missions or a fan of mauling any being you come into contact with. The cutscene styles are amazing, giving you access to limited colours that mainly consist of red, and the occasional blue from a computer screen (not blue screen of death). These cutscenes are very well animated and great to watch. It isn't only those scenes that are greatly satisfying though, when you 'consume' a specific target in the game, you are able to access their memories and previous thoughts or just be able to access the correct information you are looking for. These scenes are also well animated and well thought through, they don't give you a lot of easily noticeable imagery as it skips between images and people and small clips very quickly, but, that also makes it all the better to watch as it is mainly the talking that allows you to breifly understand what is going on in the fast paced images. Furthermore, the gameplay is relatively smooth, but it moves around and sends you of course more often than I had hoped, I have played the console version of this game and I would have to say that it was not much different to this one really, just, the controls are a lot easier to understand as there are a lot less buttons to press and hold. So, I would encourage you to use a controller rather than the keyboard. Overall, the rating of this game would be 7/10. If you found this helpful. You're welcome.

reviewText:
This game is the junkfood of sandbox action adventures.

The graphics are nothing to be astounded by, alongside the boring, repetitive enviroment. Nor should you think about the story and it's baby-eating evil cast. On those merits, this game would be terrible.

BUT, what this game does well, is let you run around the streets of New York as an unstoppable monster, fighting both infected and military enemies with incerdible ease. Though the fighting can be a bit fiddly, it's fun, frantic and empowering.

It's quick, dirty and cheap fun. Why not?

reviewText: I played the first Prototype (and enjoyed it) on the PS3 few years back. I thought the first game was good for the time and was hoping for a second one to be released. When I saw the advertisement for the Prototype2  I just had no reaction to it and decided to add this title to my maybe pile for the future. So when it came up on steam deals I toke a chance and got it. The game is very similar to the original in both good and bad ways, The combat feels the same which if you didn't like the first game then you won't like this. The story is mediocre at best (compared to modern standards) with no real connection with the main character, which could leave most people possibly disinterested on following the game till the end. However James Heller is a badass character himself and they could of created a much better back story for him. This may seem like I'm ripping on the game but, it falls down at most of the points it needs to hit. There are some features of the game which are original and with work (possibly in a Third Prototype game) they would have chance to shine. All in all if you liked the first one then pick this up (on a deal of course).

reviewText:
If you can remember it, this is pretty much like the first prototype.

Mostly the same mechanics, but a bit more polished. Less challenge missions, and harder to fail them. Pretty much ez-mode all the way through on Normal difficulty (with only a couple of speedbumps along the way) but I honestly wouldn't recommend you play it any other way. It's a power fantasy, through and through, and that's how it plays best.

Controls on keyboard & mouse are fine. A bit wonky at times, but you'll get used to them. It's a console port, so a controller is probably better if you got one. No dealbreaker though. I played through it without one easily.

There's a few bugs the developers never fixed, but since it's a 4 years old title at this point random folks on the internet has already solved them for you. AMD users (allegedly) needs a registry fix to play, and there's a point in the second mission where you have to alt-tab out and set CPU affinity to just CPU 0 for a few minutes to get past a glitchy trigger-event (the Pounce Claw Attack tutorial). Other than that, I experienced no technical problems at all throughout the rest of the game (running Nvidia and Core I7).

Bottom line: It's a non-stop action fest of gore and destruction for 12-14 hours.
If you like action games and it's on a sale, it's absolutely worth it.

reviewText:
Finished (did the last main mission) after 28 hours.
These were ca. 23 pure fun, blood, action and carnage.
And the last 5 hours PURE frustration. The last mission.
This really bad last mission which kills all the fun you had all that time.
If you would just play the mission without dying, it would be, don't know 15 minutes.
It took me 5 hours to beat the END BOSS. ♥♥♥♥ it!

Until then, I had a main stories, some side stories, action without end
and the feeling that I am the overpowered king of the city.
At least until 3 infected or 4 attack helicopters or worse, all at the same time came at me.
Then it would become even more hectic and fun.
And sometimes I died... in the beginning.

You get more and more powers, but not so many that you get confused.
A lot of your upgrades are passive ones or only useable in certain situations,
like destroy tank with one attack, or do that attack 75% faster or
run x% faster or have more health or have more hounds" in your pack.

All updates are useful somehow
date:
you can take enemy helicopters after a while and
just use them or glide around the city and do attacks from above or
ignore the main story and have fun.

The game did not crash once in these 28 hours.
And I do not have a special computer.:
Processor	Intel(R) Core(TM)2 Quad CPU    Q9550  @ 2.83GHz
hoursPlayed: 4 Core(s)
voteText:
4 Logical Processor(s)
Name	NVIDIA GeForce GTX 660 Ti
8 GB RAM

I was able to run it with max details and no fps problems at all.

reviewText:
The core idea and story are great, especially for someone like me, a fan of horror films like Carpenter's The Thing, and someone who's always liked the idea of playing the monster in a game (whether misunderstood or just plain monstrous).

They've continued the interesting atmospheric world from the first game, where the military is brutal and uncaring as a whole, the corporations are greedy and amoral, but both contain sympathetic and helpful individuals.

And the gameplay is fairly simple, but somewhat challenging (at least on hard difficulty), and very good at making you feel like you're the evolved, shapeshifting, deadly soldier James Heller.

Note that my longer list of CONS below just indicates that I saw lots of room for improvement... but I still enjoyed the game.

PROS:
- Great story.
- A rare offering in a genre without many contenders.
- Some beautiful, visceral attack effects.
- Fun if simple gameplay.

CONS:
- The end battle really undoes the playstyle you develop through the rest of the game, sort of making you learn a new game.
- Littered with sexism and anti-intellectualism... and not all of it can be chalked up to But that's just how this character thinks." Some of it is fundamental to the game's overall outlook.
- Some of the textures and modelling from the main game are too low-res for the in-game cutscenes. In those cases
date: they look awful.\n- Not as sandbox-y as the first game.\n- Character skills/customization is fairly broad and doesn't really let you specialize too much. So by late game
recommended:
your character will play pretty much the same as any other playthrough.
- As a result of the above two points: not much replayability.

Rating: 8/10"
hoursPlayed: December 6, 2013

reviewText:
Pretty awesome game!

Ignore the people that hate the game because it won't load. AMD graphics cards aren't consistent, so any good graphics games (not just Prototype 2) will run like crap.

Anyways on to the actual review -


Presentation: The storyline is interesting, but Heller's constant anger causes a lack of character development. The cutscenes are very unique and finding locations in the map is fairly easy.

Graphics: The graphics are pretty good, but they seem kind of old style. I think of Assassins creed 3/AC Brotherhood when i see the graphics.

Sound: A lot of commotion goes on and honestly some of the stuff gets annoying to hear, but nothing beats hearing the sound of your enemy getting ripped in half.

Gameplay: Your character is a badass which is what makes me addicted to this game. It's extremely entertaining to blow up helicopters and just kill everything. The only complaint is that you need the DLC to get 100% on the storyline.

Lasting Appeal: The campaign isn't too long, but you'll stay busy with all the side missions and collectibes scattered everywhere.

reviewText:
Visceral, action filled and full of the satisfying dismemberment of the poor sods who get in the way of of a virtually indomitable superhuman consumed by a biological virus. It's an open world game in the spirit of the classic 'Incredible Hulk Ultimate Destruction' on the original Xbox. Set in the aftermath of the first game, yet again NYC becomes the victim of a biological apocalpyse set off by Alex Mercer dragging in Gentek and Blackwatch. Mercer infects a soldier, Heller, who develops the powers of his protege as he goes on a rampage killing anything and everything from both sides of the conflict in a quest for revenge for his daughter.

The free roam mechanics in this game are without question the best out of any game I've played. It is simply satisfying to run at superhuman through the war torn streets of New York, leaping up the sides of skycrapers and cruising along them then jumping and gliding high above the conflict. The sense of weight and power you carry without feeling cumbersome or bulky is just nailed, you look and feel like a lithe, dealdly human predator. Story and side missions along with the usual collectilbes are scattered around the map, which is split into 3 seperate parts. While I lost the sense of a large city I got from the first, it let all the elements of the map have personality, which is a tradeoff I'm willing to take.

The weapons and upgrades are disappointedly almost the same as number one with only a few differences. They are all still visually impressive and satisfying, but I held expectations for a more substantial roster of weapon options. The combat and movements mechanics are likewise similar with a familiar set of enemies, with just enough changes to justify its existence as a new game. The Evolved are quite cool though, plus it provides an enemy that plays and operates similar to yourself. The difficulty level is quite easy once you have a few upgrades, the tools at your disposal allow you to ignore or avoid almost all incoming damage sources. My first playthough on hard was very straightforward.

Prototype 2 is not the best game ever. I haven't even bothered to review the story, because there's really nothing to say. It's passable if that, but it does its job in giving you a reason to tear though a collapsing city under siege. There isn't the greatest expansion in concepts from the first game, but enough to add some mild spice. Despite this, Prototype 2 is fun. It's simply fun, the core gameplay is nailed down so very well, fun is all a game needs to be.

reviewText:
I'll have to admit that I never played the first PROTOTYPE even though I own it since I found the controls to be horrible. Luckily, it's been fixed in this successor.

Controls are okay in this game. You will jump in the wrong direction every now and then but it's not too annoying. Graphics as well as sound are at least decent. And now the most important part: Gameplay.

The devs did a great job here in my opinion. The missions are motivating and fun. Sadly, they are a bit repetitive as well. A good thing as well is the fact that you are being rewarded for doing the whole collectible stuff. This should be mandatory in every game including those.

tl;dr: A great Open World game. If you don't feel like playing games like Saint's Row or GTAV, you may definitely grab this title in a sale since it's great fun for a couple of hours.

reviewText:
This is one of the best games I've played in a long time. I have 100%'d the game and gotten every single achievement bar 2 that are impossible for me at the current time.

Amazing graphics, extremely nice engine that works perfectly on my card, I can have recording software and have the game on max, and I will be jumping from building to building in-game in about 15 seconds from when I click play. From the loading screen you just click play and you are instantly in-game.

The storyline was a little strange in some ways but definitely decent. The missions are slightly repetitive but the game's combat system is one of the best I've ever seen. No game has ever made me want to collect absolutely everything before but this game has done just that.

Would recommend, 9/10. If you want to feel like a bad ♥♥♥, play this game.

reviewText:
Prototype 2 is so utterly ridiculous that it's hard to wipe the smile from your face.

It starts out weak but ends SO MUCH, much stronger, although its missions and storyline never really rise to a level beyond “enjoyable.” Even so, it’s enormously fun as an open-world playground, especially once all of Heller’s powers are at your disposal; there are always fun ways to experiment, to cause horrific violence and to watch the hapless pedestrians scatter.

If you’re looking for an epic, hugely varied adventure, look elsewhere, but if you want a game that lets you run amok in creative, bloody ways, Prototype 2 is pretty incredible.

reviewText:
The first issue with this game is that I cannot use my mouse because of weird extreme chopiness which is not an isolated issue, meaning it is not uncommon. Fine, whatever. I have to use my xbox 360 pad which is fine I do not mind that at all. But the big issue which is why I've never finished the game is because it is one of the worst console ports I have ever seen in terms of performance. I have a nice rig where on any games that are not poorly optimized or bad ports, I get a smooth 60fps at max settings @ 1920x1080. This game, no. I get 60fps in it yea but also stuttering from bad optimization/coding. It is still playable and enjoyable for sure, just is distracting where almost all of my other games are not because they perform flawlessly.

Besides that crap, this is a very entertaining game. You get super powers and using them to fk people up is awesome and never gets old. You can tear people in half and flatten heads and all kinds of cool ways to kill dudes. It's a big improvement over the first game in terms of quality. Better sound, controls, gameplay, etc. Although just like the first game it's a bad console port job. You can send out a pulse and find guys to consume that give you side missions but it seems like they do not become an option until you finish a certain amount of the story.

Port job 4/10. Game 7.5/10

reviewText:
While the game is fun, it is horribly optimized. It will occasionally drop from 70 fps to 5, and remain there for way too long. The graphical options are completely useless, they pretty much do nothing.
On top of that, this game not running well seems like a joke, since the textures and effects reminded me of Doom.

Graphics and performance aside, it was almost painful to transition from Prototype 1 to this game. Everything just feels 100 times clunkier. Also, this game is a lot more strict about hiding your powers from the guards. This means that the fun, carefree superpowered parkour that you could do in Prototype 1 you will now have to be overly cautious with, or else so begin the mini game of running aimlessly until the game tells you you're safe.

If you're considering getting this game, get the first one instead. This will be a disappointment.

reviewText:
Can't really recommend getting this on PC. The controls are a pain in the ♥♥♥♥ when playing with keyb+mouse.
The game itself is full of males stinking with testosterone. Cursewords fly around faster than bullets and characters don't seem to have any depth at all.
The graphics are horrible for a game released in summer 2012. Textures are low-quality even at the highest settings.
And the blood. Every time you hit anyone you hit a conveniently placed 2 liter blood pack. Amazing how these poor people can afford hiding several of those under their clothes.
The AI kinda sucks too. Soldiers can't tell if you're infected even though you just fell down 50 meters, broke the pavement, and walked away unharmed.
After all the rant I will still probably play this through but it totally is not worth it's price.

reviewText:
CON

I'm not a huge fan of games where they tell you whom to play. That said, that's my main grudge against P2 -- you can't really choose what your character looks like, what his backstory is, etc. etc., and the fact that like in P1, it isn't really anyone too likeable doesn't help.

The control scheme now lets you choose two active powers versus Prototype 1's one, and while that sounds nice (especially the option to assign a slow move and a fast move, or a close range one and a long-range / area one), I didn't really find it all that useful in the game (I would assign one fast, close range attack as primary power and use it 95 % of the time, and have something like tendrils -- or later whip fist -- as a secondary for the rare cases where I needed to attack a helicopter or needed an area effect. Using each roughly 50 % for great synergy? Not so much. But maybe, that was just me.).
The downside is that while you get twice as many active skills, you have to handle them with the same number of buttons on the controller, and the controls feel less precise than in P1. Ironically, the most annoying issue wasn't even attack related; if you don't get quite the right attack, but still an attack, it's usually non-catastrophic. What I did get often enough for it to be a nuisance however was being on a stealth mission, pressing (B) to interact with some hapless soldier (usually to consume them and gain their memories; sometimes just to stop him keeping an eye on the person you came for), and instead prying lose some feature of the landscape that also happened to be close (but didn't even necessarily look like you could interact with it). And well, prying lose random ACs or oiltanks or whatever automatically raises an alert and ruins the stealth part of your mission. (This can also be an issue during melee, where you get a prompt to press (B) to consume an enemy who's been weakened enough, but who may die soon, and where in crowded locations (B) will then often select bystanders seemingly at random, all while your actual target is bleeding out.

I liked the skill system in P1 better (get XP for everything, then once you have enough XP to improve whatever skill you're interested in (i.e. buy many minor things quickly, or save up for big improvements)) vs P2's you'll level up again at so-and-so many XP
recommended: you can improve exactly one skill"
hoursPlayed: but in the end
voteText: it wasn't a huge factor.\n(That said
helpfulPercent:
the thing where you can get a skill buy eating the brain of someone who has it still exists.)

PRO

Unsurprisingly

reviewText:
I enjoyed this game more than I thought I would.  However I did have that glitch early in the game that required me to set my CPU to one core in order to move on in the story, but quickly changed it back to all 4 cores.

The 10 hour single player game is worth the price if you like Third Person open world action games.  The game ran smooth with 50+ monsters, helicopters, tanks, soldiers, and stuff flying everywhere.  Running around, flying, and parkour all was smooth/fun.

You can pick up guns, do side quests to beef up your char, or just cause massive damage to an area.  It has a bit of stealth as well, but mostly not required.  The story is just your typical - Rough tough good guy smashing bad guys and getting tricked along the way, but every hour or so you get a new method of attacking and killing so I kept rolling forward.

If you want a GTA Meets Superman, but with Zombies/Monsters/Big Cities then this is the game for you.  Just don't expect anything more than a fun smash and bash action game.

Would play again if I didn't have so many other games to play.

reviewText: Welcome To New York, NY. A city yet again ravaged by a Bio-Nightmare created by the insidious Lab Corp known as GENTEK. In this Melee Survival Horror you are the protagonist James Heller. Heller who lost everyone that he loved thanks to then terrorist MERCER and the Blacklight Virus incident. Heller suffered a murderous breakdown for a long time but then was reactivated in the Marines & sets out to Destroy MERCER. MERCER infects HELLER and turns him to his side where HELLER quickly learns of a plot behind the 2nd Bio-Outbreak. Heller finds and takes advice from a Priest he knew from back in the day. During his journey he starts putting the puzzle pieces together to find those responsible and stop them. In the city he’ll travel thru “Zones” and tackles different missions to save people and absorb/consume Bio-Mass Monsters. He’ll level along the way and gain some new & somewhat similar but revamped Powers. With these new abilities will Heller be able to stop the Bio-Outbreak and save the city, or will he find himself a Patsy used for the next level of experiments.  Morph up, Strap down & get ready to find out.

reviewText:
Prototype 2 is a highly adictive kill everbody you see type of game. However lots of other people say Prototype is better and by playing both games and watching videos. Prototype 1 Is far better. I enjoy this game a lot because it fun go around and throw people into others but this game is flawed.

1. Im not sure if im the only one but my Quad-core 3.2 Ghz, 12gb of ram and a Saphire Radeon 7850 2GB setup had real troubles being able to load certain areas in-game, mainly indoor areas.

2. The Character is Bland. He's just your generic army black dude.

3. The Tutorial is way too in your face and stops game play to explain stuff which it really doesn't need too.

4. The animation during in-game cutscenes are very robotic in the sense that they feel very Playstation 2 like.

Despite all this, the game is still really enjoyable. Being able to cause havoc in any area you wish is all ways fun, and being able to run around the whole map at nice speeds to where-ever you wish whilst carrying most cars, bins or people to the top of a tall skyscrapper. The story in most games I never really pay attention to but this one I did and I think the story isn't that bad. Without any spoilers, the main character gets the Alex Mercer virus and discovers that the people he thought were trying to help every-one were the people causing the outbreak. So you go and take down main people in both GenTek and Blackwatch to discover more.

So, in MY opinion this game is extremly fun but prehaps not worth the £20 or whatever it is in the US. Do pick this game up if it ever gets a discount. It's definetaly worth it.

reviewText:
I missed out on the first prototype, but had this the last time it was on sale with steam.  It played wonderfully on my slightly older pc, nice graphics and i found the storyline to be imersive and fun, if a bit gory, to play.  Mutate yourself into whatever type of hero, or villan, you want to be!

What I could not get my head around are the number of glitches in the game, these according to the forums have caused numerous buyers stress, the breaking point came when i reached a point in the game where i could no longer progress in the storyline as a glitch simply stopped the next mission from loading.  I'm about a third of the way into the game, and all i can do now is rampage around the map killing zombies, soldiers, or innocent civilians who get in my way.  I'm completely stuck, and there seems no way around the problem.
Uninstalling and reinstalling, wiping the temporary files, wiping all the saves and starting from scratch, nothing works as it seems for me the game is simply broken.

Steam should be ashamed to put this back on sale, without first adding a refund button you can use when it simply breaks on you for no apparent reason!

reviewText:
Prototype 2 at first was hard to really give an opinion on. You play as a marine named James Heller who's basic focus is to kill his family's murderer: Alex Mercer. Heller through 3/4's of the game is a cliche 'I'm just the perfect badass' character. And it's very irritating. No, he is not very emotional past flat out angry. While the anger is understandable, it isn't acceptable to me that a character only really acts on one feeling. You will see Heller in other emotions so don't get me wrong, he isn't the same throughout the whole story (thank God). But it's only about 3 times. Other than that, he's a cocky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that can't go a minute without swearing.

As for gameplay, that's where it took me a while. The combat at first is meteocre since you have no abilities. You just mash one button. Once you get a couple abilities that's when it starts to get fun as you can use two abilities at once rather than having to switch so much in the first title. The side missions are rinsed and repeated, but you become more powerful this way and honestly, it never really gets old being able to sneak in and destroy things by morphing into another human you just ate". They also added a timed side mission where you need to get all the intel canisters before Blackwatch gets their corrupt little hands on them. You only get two mass abilities unfortunately. The first is just the recycled devastator Mercer used. The second I don't want to spoil.

I actually like that it takes longer to unlock things in this one. You can't hijack tanks or helicopters nearly as soon as you could in the first
date: so it makes for more of a challenge. Overall
recommended: the gameplay is definitely better than the first
hoursPlayed: but I do miss the ability to body surf. And I also miss how you dig in and tear up the streets in the first one too. You don't really do that in this one. And if you're curious about the graphics....no they definitely are not better than the first. I run this on maximum settings and it still looks bad compared to the first. But I'm not a person to care as long as the game is solid.\n\nAs for the story
voteText: some say it's deeper than the first. Yeah I can agree with that to a point. The story is very predictable but done decent. Half of the story is told through the important people you steal memories from. I always liked that about Prototype. The end was a cliffhanger and left me wanting more. I hope at some point in the future they decide to make a Prototype 3 to either continue the story or add closure to it.\n\nI'd say this game is worth a max of $15 to $20. Better than the first and definitely recommended. But I always feel Prototype could do so much better with the story and immersion. Lets hope they make a Prototype 3 someday and really blow our minds with it."

8/10 - it doesn't deliver much but it excels it what it does do.

I don't know why people disliked this game or the series, I think they are solid fun games offering a good beat 'em up, great load of fun.

Not much has really changed since the first game, except that now you can equip 2 at the same time and use them interchangeably using Left and Right mouse buttons. The open world is the same, exploring is the same, except there's a little more but somehow feels more bland though...

Summary:
I really like this series and I really liked this game, I wanted to play it, never felt forced too and had a great deal of fun in the process, the storyline was a bit bland but the combat made up for it. It's a great Hack'n'Slash beat 'em up style game, with fun fights, keeps you on your toes about how you're going to kill a certain enemy (Some enemies can be killed more efficient with different attack styles) and overall I had a great deal of fun from this game - like I did with the first.
If you're looking for a game that is a Hack'n'Slash beat 'em style game with cool monsters to kill, a great movement system, fleshed out, and that flows really well then this game is for you - like it was the game for me.
Don't be fooled by it's low rating, it is by far better than any of the ♥♥♥♥ that gets 90%-95%, like ♥♥♥♥ing Goat Simulator? Give me a ♥♥♥♥ing break.

Gameplay:
It's basically a hack'n'slash beat 'em up game, very responsive and you feel powerful, it's just fun, really, I can't put it any other way because you are powerful, essentially a god in the game, but a single slip up can kill you I found - well in hard mode at least - sometimes you'll find that you're running away to eat some guys. It's still fun.
The weapons are fun, but I found myself using only 2 - the claws and the tendrils - probably because they were my most upgraded but each had their own thing, and towards the end I did switch them out. Oddly enough, there's less choice about mutations than in the first, you get 5 different powers, some have had minor changes from the first one, specials being applied to other powers and so on.
I'm not sure if it's because I haven't played the first for ages, but I felt that there were less enemies attacking, the boss fights were much smaller for sure, in this game, they did the thing where the first time you meet them they are a boss, then as you get stronger they become a regular enemy kind of thing. I kind of felt this ruined the vibe a little, made it all feel a bit... Worthless to be honest. In addition, there was no real unique boss fight like in the first game like when you fight Greene and so on. It's a shame really as it could have easily added them in and made the game much better.
Overall, the combat is very fleshed out, very responsive, makes you feel powerful and like a god. Gives the player good feedback with the health bars taking chunks of damage off and so on, generally really fun combat, great feel to the game and I never got bored of it.

Story:
I'll say this now, the first 20% of the storyline is pretty crappy, but after that it starts to get good, I felt less involved than I did in the first one though, the story felt a tad spread out and seemed to fit the game rather than the game fitting the story - unlike the first one where I felt it did the opposite. I don't want to spoil anything but I'll say this: the story kind of treats the original game as null and void, for example, Pariah isn't even mentioned ANYWHERE in the game, nor Greene. So be warned if you really like the world of Prototype because this game kind of treats it a bit unfairly.

Graphics:
In all honesty, I had some graphical issues with the game and my computer couldn't really play it properly, had some weird mouse lag thing and FPS issues so I had to play in the minimum settings. But I'll put it bluntly; not much has changed since the original but you won't be focusing on that because you'll spend all your concentration on killing the enemy. I felt it didn't need better graphics because I didn't give a ♥♥♥♥ about them as I was too preoccupied about that monster trying to kill me.

Audio:
Not really much to talk about here, you get audio options and the audio is of the typical Triple-A standard that you'll expect. That's really it in that department...

Re-playability:
Well you can 100% the game so it's got that going for it, other than that, after I finished it I uninstalled it, I have no real reason to go back to the game but having a 15 hour playtime it is enough for me. It didn't outstay it's welcome and it didn't bug me for bed & breakfast. Overall, not much re-playability but it doesn't really need any as for a story game 15 hours is pretty damn long by today's standards.

Overall, 8/10 - they could have done quite a few things better but it doesn't prevent it from being a good game, it just prevents it from being an excellent. It's a shame that they have basically abandoned this series and I really hope for the original spark in the first game to reign chaos once again and make a third that takes all the criticism both games got to make an excellent sequel. Trust me, it is definitely possible if you'd JUST BLOODY LISTEN.

- Vince

reviewText:
Loads and loads of fun. Prototype 2 took the lessons learned in Prorotype and distilled all of the most intensely fun parts into a new game. Heller is a superb protagonist, and I found myself chuckling at his snide remarks more than a few times. The powers and unlocking were all streamlined from the original. Mercer transitioned perfectly from protagonist to antagonist, and it's beautiful how in-your-face he is right off the start. It really makes the climax that much more intense.

Only criticism was that the difficulty felt a bit low. The only time I really felt any pushback was on the final Mercer fight. The rest of the game makes you feel like some kind of symbiote-deity. And that's totally all right.

In conclusion, it is a fitting sequel which surpasses the original. Well worth the buy.

reviewText:
Prototype 2 at first was hard to really give an opinion on. You play as a marine named James Heller who's basic focus is to kill his family's murderer: Alex Mercer. Heller through 3/4's of the game is a cliche 'I'm just the perfect badass' character. And it's very irritating. No, he is not very emotional past flat out angry. While the anger is understandable, it isn't acceptable to me that a character only really acts on one feeling. You will see Heller in other emotions so don't get me wrong, he isn't the same throughout the whole story (thank God). But it's only about 3 times. Other than that, he's a cocky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that can't go a minute without swearing.

As for gameplay, that's where it took me a while. The combat at first is meteocre since you have no abilities. You just mash one button. Once you get a couple abilities that's when it starts to get fun as you can use two abilities at once rather than having to switch so much in the first title. The side missions are rinsed and repeated, but you become more powerful this way and honestly, it never really gets old being able to sneak in and destroy things by morphing into another human you just ate". They also added a timed side mission where you need to get all the intel canisters before Blackwatch gets their corrupt little hands on them. You only get two mass abilities unfortunately. The first is just the recycled devastator Mercer used. The second I don't want to spoil.

I actually like that it takes longer to unlock things in this one. You can't hijack tanks or helicopters nearly as soon as you could in the first
date: so it makes for more of a challenge. Overall
recommended: the gameplay is definitely better than the first
hoursPlayed: but I do miss the ability to body surf. And I also miss how you dig in and tear up the streets in the first one too. You don't really do that in this one. And if you're curious about the graphics....no they definitely are not better than the first. I run this on maximum settings and it still looks bad compared to the first. But I'm not a person to care as long as the game is solid.\n\nAs for the story
voteText: some say it's deeper than the first. Yeah I can agree with that to a point. The story is very predictable but done decent. Half of the story is told through the important people you steal memories from. I always liked that about Prototype. The end was a cliffhanger and left me wanting more. I hope at some point in the future they decide to make a Prototype 3 to either continue the story or add closure to it.\n\nI'd say this game is worth a max of $15 to $20. Better than the first and definitely recommended. But I always feel Prototype could do so much better with the story and immersion. Lets hope they make a Prototype 3 someday and really blow our minds with it."

reviewText:
New York has been devastated by hideous mutative virus and the only hope for at least a somewhat happy outcome is a soldier wracked with PTSD, visions of his lost family and on a quest for vengeance… Oh and he is literally an indestructible super mutant. Sound fun? Then you should get this game.

Now where to start, this game is more fun than a barrel full of radioactive plague monkeys hopped up on Vicodin. This game takes place a few years after the events of the first title, knowledge of which is not needed as you get a history lesson almost immediately before getting infected with the super virus that turns you into a freaking super hero… of death I guess.

The game offers you three large open worlds to explore, each representing a portion of New York city and each very different in their own way. If you’ve seen NY then you will know your way around. Yellow zone is a huge slum where the oppressive totalitarian Government crushes all under boot, the green zone is… well much the same as NY now but the red zone, that’s where it’s at. Huge packs of rabid mutants roam the streets, the buildings toppled and destroyed. I loved that place.

The combat is one of the best parts of this or any other game. As mentioned you are a super hero, sorta. You can fly, jump over skyscrapers rip people in half, hurl tanks into other tanks and all that cool stuff. Not only that but you come with more blades than a Swiss army knife and each one of deadly powers is so much fun to use. My fav was infection citizens and turning them into living goop bombs before lobbing them at passers-by and watching the carnage.

This game makes you feel like a bad a.s.s, the most bad a.s.sed bad a.s.s that ever roamed the streets of NYC. With your array of powers you could destroy entire armies or mutants and humans alike. Slicing, dicing and smashing them to bits before transforming into someone else and walking away as if nothing’s happened. This game gives you the power to be anyone; You just have to consume them. That’s right, your powers health and abilities rely on how many people you can eat using your tentacles. All of the things you can possibly imagine are given to you via a large tech tree and levelling system.

Not only can you use your bare hands to deal a lot of damage there are also vehicles in this game too. Tanks, helicopters and..… Well not many different vehicles but each one can blow the heck out of anything infront of it. You can also utilize your enemies weapons, slicing someone apart and then blowing up his friends with his grenade launcher, classic.

The story is great too, a man’s tale of vengeance, betrayal and hope lead him to save the world from a psychopath hell bent on forcing humanities evolution. Also there is a government conspiracy in there somewhere. The characters are great and I felt really connected to the protagonist, just like everyone else he absorbs. The music was good, not great but it served its purpose. There are a ton of collectables that offer a nice amount of back story and hidden information and I had a good time tracking them all down.

This game is awesome; there is a lot of enjoyment to be had. It is not overly long even though its open world but what’s there will entertain you for hours. Plus if you are anything like me the pure gory death you inflict on others is enough to get me hooked. Buy this allday anyday and you will not be diapointed.

Have Fun ^_^

reviewText:
when it comes to Prtototype 2 i have mixed feelings...

on the one hand:
+we have a great story
+nice game mechanics
+a fun and kinda unique way to ,literally, run around the whole map
+a well designed hack and slash all in all

on the other hand:
-THIS GAME IS SOOO BADLY AND POORLY PORTED TO THE PC-VERSION

many people complain about start up crashes and such things. my problem was that if i wanted to watch a cutscene ingame i was caught in an endless loading screen afterwards and needed to restart the game. So I was forced to skip all cutscenes in order to avoid it and watch them in a seperate video on youtube... that is really a huge downside since the story is good and also playing a mission without any backround is just slayin some mutants.

So i can recommend the game to everybody who likes open world or hack n slay games but you need to be patient with all the hickups the PC version contains and because of all the problems only buy it in a sale if you are interested.

IF you have the possibility, play it on a console.

reviewText:
I cannot play this game, I'm mostly just writing this to let others know that this is a ♥♥♥♥ port. Stay away from this on PC, avoid it like it has the plague. I honestly would love a refund for my money, and time spent trying to fix something that should have already been fixed.

Edit: I did get this to start working with my AMD card, there is a wonderful topic in the discussion board that helped, but that still does not change the fact that I would not recommend buying this on a PC, it crashes frequently, and I've had sound cut out on cutscenes at odd times.
As for the game itself the story is actually pretty decent, the game is more of the same of prototype so it is fun at times, but the combat feels lacking compared to the first one, this is partially due to having two powers out at once now, and one button is used for either power.
Overall I would say it's average for fun, but if you did kind of enjoy the plot of prototype, I did, then this is not a must play immediately but I say an eventually, like you know three years later.

reviewText:
The game worked perfectly for me, not sure why other people can't run it.

The game was a good and fun experience. Not as much of a thrill as that first time you learned each power in Prototype1, but it has its moments.

Using stealth to avoid unnecessary combat was always my favorite option, but when I had to fight, I would always call in my Brawlers. Some might consider having five large allies as a mechanic that ruins the game experience, but you can always choose to go at it solo if you prefer.

There were a few things I did not like in this game, but they were tollerable:
Defensive misions
Powerless Blackwatch missions
Timed collect the cargo" mission
There is always an easy way to win a fight and a hard way. The game lets you pick which one you want to try most of the time because it is an open world.

The game encourages you to do side missions and level up because you become more badass and powerful with each upgrade. With the right upgrades
date: the game can become more and more fun.\n\nGlad I bought this game
recommended: I will revisit it some day when I want to run through both the games and relive everything again."

reviewText: I was happy to get this game at first till I started playing it.  First thing I always do before starting a game is go into options.  That section of the game was broken right of the bat. I wanted to select screen resolution and check key bindings.  None of this was possible.  Started the game I quickly found out when it said use left mouse botton only, the right botton worked.  Then when the game said to use right button to siphon life and restore health, no button anyplace on the keyboard or mouse worked. The game was stuck.  I had to alt + delete to quit the game.  Did some google searching and found lots of issues with this game starting with non Nvidia Gfx cards to changeing mouse configurations.  Meeting the system requirements fully, this should not happen.  So I take my thumbs up on this game back and warn others.  This game is  not worth buying.

reviewText: To people not familiar with Prototype 1, I recommend it, it's a power fantasy and a lot of fun. There are references to the first game but it's not needed to have a fun time. This game is a Power Fantasy and it does that in spades, you feel powerful. Enjoy. My review below is for people who have played and enjoyed the plot and storyline of the original Prototype.\n\nTo fans of the original Prototype, this game is about the same. It's a big more organized, with a bit more work put into it. But it has the same progression and feels very much like you are just playing the original Prototype with a few extras added in. If you feel a Prototype itch" this may be a decent game to pick up if it was heavily discounted
date: but I generally do not recommend this game. I do not recommend it because the completion of this game left a bad taste in my mouth. I enjoyed the original Protoype
recommended: and loved the story and the plot. But this game throws it all away. Because (Spoilers)  Alex Mercer
hoursPlayed: the original protagonist

reviewText:
HORRIBLE PORT!

This game is just unplayable. I cannot even start the game and I have done everything I can, including updating the 'driver's which is a typical/copy-paste response for any technical team. I have the system able to run GTA V, come on! When I verify the game cache it always says that there is just one file that isn't right and it never downloads it no matter if I restart steam fully or restart my computer.

Some say it is the graphics card and now I am beginning to think it is that... AMD has a LOT of problems running it, and funnily enough I have a AMD graphics card. AMD Radeon HD 6800 Series.

Perhaps you may get it to work by disabling many things on your computer or buy a new graphics card, but if one person has to go through all that trouble just to start it, the game has some serious issues and possibly more in store. The developers don't even care to fix this problem as it has been a problem for some time now as I realized. I am not even sure why Steam is even selling this at all because it's a complete failure as a port to PC.

Don't think the developers care as long as they get the $$$

Thank god for refund options or my friend would be screwed gifting me this. Otherwise, I suggest getting the console version and play it on there instead and maybe then you might have some fun!
